key_mistakes.reason: The move c6 was suboptimal as it led to a weakened pawn structure and did not address the development of pieces or control of the center. It was a passive move that allowed White to improve their position.
Nbd7 was a mistake because it blocked the c8 bishop and did not contribute to the central control or development.
The castling move was a mistake as it overlooked the opportunity to challenge White’s central pawn structure and improve Black’s pawn structure.
Moving the knight to e8 was a mistake because it retreated an active piece to a passive position rather than capturing White’s strong knight on e5.
Capturing on g5 with the bishop allowed White to gain significant material advantage through tactical sequences.
The move allowed White to further consolidate their position and eventually resulted in a favorable exchange for White.

recommendations: Focus on developing pieces actively, prioritizing central control.
Avoid passive moves that weaken pawn structure without gaining compensation.
Consider tactical possibilities to exploit opponent's weaknesses.
Maintain flexibility in piece positioning to respond to opponent's threats.
